items.title: Six killed as Iran protests spread beyond Tehran

featured_image.name: Deaths reported during widening protests in Iran sparked by ailing economy

items.description:
At least six people have died as demonstrations over Iran's collapsing economy spread from Tehran to rural provinces, marking the deadliest unrest since the country's 2022 protest movement. The fatalities, which occurred between Wednesday night and Thursday evening, signal an escalation in tensions between Iranian authorities and protesters demanding relief from runaway inflation and currency depreciation[1][2][3][4].

Iranian authorities confirmed that a 21-year-old member of the Basij paramilitary force was killed late Wednesday in Kuhdasht, a city in western Lorestan province, with officials claiming he died "defending public order" as 13 other security personnel sustained injuries[3][5][6]. On Thursday, the semi-official Fars news agency reported five additional deaths across Lorestan and Chaharmahal and Bakhtiari provinces, including two people killed in Lordegan and three in Azna during clashes with security forces[3][7][8].

The protests erupted Sunday after shopkeepers in Tehran's historic Grand Bazaar shuttered their businesses in response to the rial plunging to approximately 1.45 million per U.S. dollar, down from 820,000 rials just one year ago[9][10][11]. According to Iran's Statistical Center, annual inflation reached 42.2 percent in December, with food prices soaring 72 percent year-over-year[9][12]. The demonstrations have since expanded to multiple cities including Isfahan, Shiraz, Mashhad, Hamadan, and Zanjan, with students joining merchants in the streets[13][10][14].

items.title: China's anti-pollution crusade linked to Australian bushfires
items.description: As China caps off a historic clean-up of its smog and air pollution, the clearer air is helping temperatures rise to new records. Now, researchers are linking that change to hotter and drier conditions in Australia.

items.title: China's beef tariffs aren't about Australia
items.description: Beijing's new measures are aimed at trying to rein in an Australian surge and manage local growth, rather than a direct target on Australia.

items.title: Russia hands US alleged drone evidence as CIA rejects Putin attack claim
items.description:
Russia delivered what it described as physical evidence to the United States on Thursday, claiming it proves Ukraine targeted President Vladimir Putin's residence in a drone attack, even as the CIA and Western officials have flatly rejected Moscow's account as disinformation[1][2][3].

Admiral Igor Kostyukov, head of Russia's military intelligence agency, handed a U.S. military attache a navigation controller recovered from a downed drone, according to video footage released by Russia's Defense Ministry[1][4][5]. Russian officials asserted that decoded data from the device confirms the intended target was Putin's residence in the Novgorod region during an alleged December 29 attack involving 91 drones[1][3][6].

items.title: Greens member 'blindsides' Tasmanian party by quitting
items.description: The Clark MP says she knows the decision "will be disappointing for some," but it is necessary for her to be "effective" in parliament — a move that has "blindsided" her former colleagues.

items.title: Lachie Neale apologises for actions that led to marriage breakdown
items.description: The club said the 32-year-old had made the decision following a "challenging personal period".

items.title: SpaceX plans to lower 4,400 satellites in 2026 for safety

featured_image.name: SpaceX buys spectrum for Starlink 'Direct to Cell' mobile service

items.description:
The telecommunications industry is racing to integrate satellite and terrestrial networks by 2030, with major carriers rolling out direct-to-cell services and researchers mapping the technical roadmap for seamless global coverage.

A comprehensive study published December 29 in the journal Engineering outlines how satellite communication systems will become integral to 5G and future 6G networks, enabling smartphones to automatically switch between cell towers and orbiting satellites[1][2]. The research, authored by Afang Yuan, Zhihua Yang, and Zhili Sun, identifies key technical challenges including managing handoffs between fast-moving satellites, preventing orbital collisions, and coordinating radio frequencies[3][1].

The International Telecommunication Union has designated 2030 as the target for 6G deployment, with specifications requiring not just faster speeds but seamless integration between ground-based infrastructure and satellites orbiting at various altitudes[3][1]. While today's 5G networks deliver peak speeds of 10 gigabits per second, the upcoming 6G standard aims for 1 terabit per second[3].

items.title: Khawaja's on-field brilliance pales in comparison to his true impact
items.description: Before his debut in 2011, Australia had never seen a cricketer like Usman Khawaja and, thanks to his work on and off the field, he'll be followed by plenty more.

items.title: Sydney mother identified as one of three drowning victims in NSW
items.description: The identity of one of three people who died in a cluster of drownings on the New South Wales coast in recent days has been confirmed as a Sydney hairdresser and mother.

items.title: 'My greatest blessings': Khawaja's emotional retirement message
items.description: Australia batter Usman Khawaja announces he will retire from international cricket after the fifth and final Ashes Test at the SCG, which starts on Sunday.

items.title: Chinese tokamak exceeds density limit in fusion advance

featured_image.name: China sets new fusion endurance record of over a thousand seconds

items.description:
Researchers at China's Experimental Advanced Superconducting Tokamak have achieved stable plasma operation at densities far exceeding a long-standing empirical limit, marking a potential breakthrough in the decades-long pursuit of practical fusion energy.

The team demonstrated plasma densities ranging from 1.3 to 1.65 times the Greenwald limit, an empirical threshold above which tokamaks typically experience disruptive instabilities[1][2][3]. The achievement, detailed in recent research, represents the first experimental verification of a theorized "density-free regime" predicted by plasma-wall self-organization theory[1][3].

The research, co-led by Prof. Zhu Ping from Huazhong University of Science and Technology and Associate Prof. Yan Ning from the Hefei Institutes of Physical Science, addresses a fundamental challenge in fusion energy development[1][2][3]. Fusion power scales with the square of fuel density, making high-density operation crucial for achieving the energy output needed for commercial viability[1][3].

items.title: Astronomers measure mass of Saturn-sized rogue planet

featured_image.name: Rare Saturn-sized rogue planet is first to have its mass measured

items.description:
Astronomers have achieved a milestone in planetary science by measuring the mass of a free-floating planet for the first time, using observations from both ground-based and space telescopes. The Saturn-sized world, designated KMT-2024-BLG-0792, represents a breakthrough in understanding these enigmatic objects that drift through the galaxy without a parent star[1][2].

The international research team, led by Subo Dong of Peking University, published their findings in the journal Science on January 1[3][1][4]. By observing a brief microlensing event simultaneously from Earth's surface and the European Space Agency's Gaia space telescope, they determined the planet has a mass roughly 0.7 times that of Saturn—or about 22 percent of Jupiter's mass—and lies approximately 10,000 light-years from Earth[3][1][5][6].

"What's really great about this work, and really noteworthy, is that it's the first time we've got a mass for these objects," said Gavin Coleman, a postdoctoral researcher at Queen Mary University of London who authored a related commentary in Science[4]. Previous detections of rogue planets could only estimate masses indirectly, leaving much about these solitary worlds speculative[3].

items.title: Australian injured as survivors blame sparklers for Swiss blaze that killed around 40
items.description: Swiss authorities say "a large number of young people" are among the casualties from a fire at the Crans-Montana ski resort, as work continues to identify "dozens" of dead bodies.

items.title: Easter Island researchers say giant statues 'walked' into position
items.description: A study using 11,600 aerial drone photos to map a mountainous quarry in 3D reveals more about how the island's famed stone sentinels were created and moved to their final resting places.

items.title: Several killed as Iran protests over economy turn deadly

featured_image.name: Iran's protests led by shopkeepers is shaking up the regime

items.description:
Violent clashes between protesters and security forces left several people dead across Iran on January 1, marking the most deadly escalation yet in demonstrations that erupted four days earlier over soaring inflation and a collapsing currency[1][2][3][4]. The unrest represents the largest wave of protests in Iran since 2022, when the death of Mahsa Amini sparked nationwide demonstrations[1][2][3].

Semi-official media and rights groups reported multiple fatalities in at least three provinces. Fars news agency said two people were killed in Lordegan, a city in western Iran, during clashes between security services and protesters[5][6][7]. The human rights organization Hengaw corroborated deaths in Lordegan, saying security forces opened fire on demonstrators[8][5][9]. Another death was reported in Isfahan province in central Iran[5][6][7].

Authorities confirmed one person killed in Kuhdasht, a western city, though accounts of the incident diverged sharply. State media identified the deceased as Amirhossam Khodayari Fard, a 21-year-old member of the Basij paramilitary unit[2][5][10][7]. The Revolutionary Guards said 13 other militia members were wounded and accused demonstrators of "taking advantage of the atmosphere of popular protests"[7][5]. However, Hengaw said Khodayari Fard was a protester killed by security forces[5][6][7]. Reuters could not independently verify the reports[7][4].

items.title: Interstellar object traced to Milky Way core; no alien signals detected

featured_image.name: Rare Interstellar Object 3I/ATLAS Fails Alien Test, Scientists Say

items.description:
The interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS has been traced to the violent heart of the Milky Way, while the most sensitive radio search ever conducted on such an object found no evidence of artificial technology, scientists reported in late December 2025.

Discovered on July 1, 2025, by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System in Chile, 3I/ATLAS is only the third confirmed object from another star system to enter our solar neighborhood[1][2][3][4]. Recent observations have pinpointed its origin to the direction of Sagittarius, a corridor leading to the galaxy's turbulent core roughly 26,000 light-years away[2][3][5].

"It has been approaching from the general direction of the constellation Sagittarius, which is where the central region of our galaxy, the Milky Way, is located," NASA confirmed[5]. The object's trajectory and hyperbolic excess velocity of approximately 58 kilometers per second suggest it was ejected from a high-energy environment marked by intense radiation and dense stellar traffic[1][2][3].

items.title: Fire kills dozens at Swiss ski resort bar during New Year's

featured_image.name: Fire tears through bar at Swiss Alps ski resort Crans-Montana during New Year's celebrations

items.description:
A devastating fire tore through a packed bar in the Swiss Alps early Thursday morning, killing several dozen people and injuring around 100 others as revelers celebrated the arrival of 2026. The blaze at Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana erupted around 1:30 AM local time, transforming a festive New Year's gathering into what authorities described as one of Switzerland's worst tragedies[1][2][3][4][5][6][7].

"Several tens of people" were presumed dead, Valais Canton police commander Frédéric Gisler said during a news conference Thursday morning, though he emphasized it was premature to provide a precise figure as work continues to identify victims and notify families[1][3][6][7]. The Italian foreign ministry, citing Swiss police, estimated around 40 fatalities[4][8][9]. More than 100 people were inside the bar when the fire broke out, witnesses and officials said[2][5][6].

items.title: Not a 'blip': Sydney and Melbourne property prices go into reverse
items.description: The red-hot Australian housing market is showing the first signs of easing since interest rates started rising in May 2022.

items.title: Satellites to enable seamless global 5G and 6G by 2030

featured_image.name: AST SpaceMobile Launches Its Most Powerful Direct-to-Cell ...

items.description:
Satellite communication systems are poised to integrate with terrestrial mobile networks by 2030, eliminating dead zones and delivering the next generation of wireless connectivity to billions of smartphones worldwide, according to a comprehensive analysis published this week in the journal Engineering.

The article, "Evolution of Satellite Communication Systems Toward 5G/6G for 2030 and Beyond," reviews how satellites at various orbital altitudes will combine with ground-based infrastructure to form a unified 5G and 6G communications platform[1][2][3]. The International Telecommunication Union has designated 2030 as the target for deploying IMT-2030—the official designation for 6G—which aims to deliver peak speeds of 1 terabit per second, a hundredfold increase over current 5G networks[4][5].

items.title: US says Ukraine did not target Putin in drone strike
items.description:
U.S. national security officials determined that Ukraine did not target Russian President Vladimir Putin or his residences in a recent drone strike, contradicting Moscow's allegations and casting doubt on claims that threaten to derail peace negotiations.

The assessment, backed by the Central Intelligence Agency, found no evidence Ukraine aimed at Putin in the alleged December 28-29 incident, according to a U.S. official familiar with the intelligence[1][2][3]. The finding was first reported by The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday[4][5].

Russia claimed on Monday that Ukraine launched 91 long-range attack drones at Putin's Valdai residence in the Novgorod region, calling it a "terrorist attack"[6][7][8]. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said all drones were intercepted and warned Moscow would revise its negotiating position[7][9][8]. However, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy swiftly dismissed the allegations as "another lie" intended to sabotage diplomatic progress[9][10].

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
